entry.title: Compliance in the Age of AI: How SAP GRC’s Regulatory Insights is Redefining Risk Management
entry.content:
The Silent Storm of Non-Compliance

It’s 7:15 AM and Priya Nair, Chief Compliance Officer (CCO) at a global pharmaceutical giant, receives a regulatory update from the European Medicines Agency. She sends it to her team, already anticipating a flurry of urgent responses and braces herself for another fire drill.

New regulations mean changes to internal controls. This means hundreds of person-hours reviewing documents, comparing frameworks, updating controls, notifying teams, and preparing for audits. All this—while staying ahead of business goals.

For Priya, and thousands like her, this is not a once-in-a-while event. This is daily life.

Introduction: 

In today’s hyper-regulated environment, where 250+ regulatory change events occur each day, manual compliance processes are no longer sustainable.

Enter: SAP Process Control with Regulatory Insights, a breakthrough SAP GRC innovation built on SAP BTP, powered by AI and Generative AI, that’s helping professionals like Priya flip the compliance narrative from reactive to proactive—and from cost-center to competitive edge.

The Compliance Conundrum: A Modern Enterprise Challenge

Today’s enterprises are dealing with:

  • Constantly evolving regulations (think GDPR, SOX, NIST, COBIT, MaRisk…)
  • Siloed compliance efforts across business units
  • Inconsistent control documentation
  • Audit fatigue
  • Fear of non-compliance fines, loss of reputation, and erosion of stakeholder trust

Manual processes for control mapping, documents handling is error prone, cost intensive and increases risks as well as burnouts.

The Game Changer: SAP Process Control with Regulatory Insights

Now let’s zoom into the innovation.

At the heart of this solution lies the SAP Process Control and Regulatory Insights service—on BTP, an AI-powered application designed to interpret, extract, compare and map control requirements across evolving regulatory documents.

                                    

 

Let’s break it down through personas in a real-world narrative.

  1. Priya Nair – Chief Compliance Officer

Pain Point: Challenged and facing mounting pressure by increasingly complex regulatory landscape.
Solution:

With AI-powered Regulatory Insights, Priya’s team can now automatically extract control requirements from large regulatory documents using NLP and machine learning. These are uploaded through the Import Control Requirements App into SAP Process Control.

Impact: Hours of manual reading and interpretation reduced to minutes. Regulations are now available in GRC system as meaningful control definitions.
“It’s like having a legal expert and a data analyst rolled into one AI assistant” , Priya says.

2. Carlos Menendez – Control Owner in Finance

Pain Point: Updating internal controls with every regulatory change
Solution:

                                        

Using the Manage Control Requirements App, Carlos can quickly create or update internal controls—both centrally and locally—linked to his business processes.

Impact: Faster response to regulatory change. Controls are tracked, assigned, and monitored periodically.
“I no longer rely on spreadsheets and emails—I now have a control cockpit” , Carlos shares.

3. Jennifer Shen – Internal Auditor

Pain Point: Identifying what changed in a regulation
Solution:

                                    

With Delta Analysis, Jennifer compares two versions of a regulatory framework and instantly sees what’s added, removed, or modified.

Impact: Audit readiness improves drastically. Summary reports help prioritize control updates and decision-making.


“What took days of manual review now takes seconds” , she smiles.

What Frameworks Are Supported?

Currently live within SAP SE environments, the solution supports:

  • C5
  • COBIT
  • FitSM
  • GHB
  • MaRisk
  • NIST
  • SOX

                                       

And this is just a beginning…

What’s Coming Next (Q3–Q4 2025)?

  • Control Gap Analysis – Automatically detect gaps between existing controls and new regulations.

  • Control Coverage Analysis – Suggest additional controls using Gen AI, ensuring better control coverage.

  • Process Orchestration – Enhanced sync between SAP Process Control and Regulatory Insights, helping drive resilience.

Business Benefits: From Cost Center to Strategic Advantage

  • Significant Cost Savings: With ~250 regulatory change events a day, savings range between USD 50K to USD 250K just from automation and reduced manual effort.
  • Audit Readiness: Continuous delta analysis means controls are always audit-ready.
  • Smarter Risk Management: Proactively mitigate non-compliance risks and enhance stakeholder trust.
  • Strategic Focus: Free up experts from mundane tasks—redirect efforts toward innovation and strategic resilience.

Conclusion: Turning Compliance Into Competitive Advantage

In a world where trust is the currency of business, non-compliance is not an option.

SAP Process Control with Regulatory Insights is not just another GRC tool—it’s a strategic partner for organizations that want to stay compliant, agile, and ahead of change.

                                     

                                        

By leveraging AI and Gen AI, it automates the interpretation of complex regulatory language, links it to enterprise controls, and ensures your business is always one step ahead of regulators.

For CCOs like Priya, Control Owners like Carlos, and Auditors like Jennifer,  it is not just about managing risks - it is about enabling trusted growth.

Key Takeaways

  • Automate regulatory interpretation and control mapping
  • Instantly compare evolving regulations and identify control changes
  • Save costs and person-hours through AI-powered insights
  • Build resilient and audit-ready internal control environments
  • Future-proof compliance strategy with AI-led innovation

Want to see how SAP GRC with Regulatory Insights can transform your compliance posture? 

Chandan Kalra, Director, GRC, Product Engineering | Srinath Ganesan, Director, Finance  & Risk

This session provided best practices for creating and managing business roles that align with organizational needs while reducing permission sprawl. We showcased how IAG’s role-based approach supports scalability and enforces least-privilege principles as the organization evolves.

We concluded with a deep dive into hybrid governance strategies, demonstrating how SAP Access Control andSAP Cloud Identity Access Governance can work together for consistent policy enforcement across cloud and on-premise environments. The session covered data synchronization, risk sharing, and role management in integrated scenarios, offering a low-disruption pathway to cloud adoption.

This campaign reaffirmed the power of our user community, not just as consumers of technology but as active contributors to shaping its evolution. We look forward to continuing this journey together with more sessions, resources, and opportunities to connect.

entry.title: SAP Exception Handling and Auto Remediation with AI Agents
entry.content:
Agentic AI in SAP Exception Management

Introduction:

Enterprises running SAP can relate to this moment: month-end is approaching, the finance team is reconciling accounts, the procurement is chasing approvals, and the operations are working overtime to close orders. Then it happens: an exception surfaces. A blocked invoice. A missing goods receipt. A foreign currency posting that doesn’t add up.

From the eagle eye view this might seem just a minor technical error. But the reality? They halt business processes, disrupt vendor payments, distort financial reporting, and expose the enterprise to compliance risks.

For example: A global retail enterprise once faced an inventory discrepancy exception. In SAP, the system records showed stock available for sale, but in reality, the physical warehouse had no such stock. This type of exception occurs in SAP Materials Management (MM) and Inventory Management (IM), and often spreads into Production Planning (PP) and Sales & Distribution (SD) because customer orders are created based on inaccurate stock levels.

The impact was significant: customers placed orders that couldn’t be fulfilled, leading to stockouts during peak season. Operations teams scrambled to explain, procurement rushed to source emergency materials, and finance recorded lost revenue. In just one quarter, the company estimated over USD 3 million in lost sales, in addition to reputational damage and strained customer relationships.

In this digital world where uptime, accuracy and punctuality define competitiveness, an exception like this becomes a huge boardroom issue and requires modern and proactive solutions to tackle.

Exceptions in SAP – A Business Reality

An exception in SAP is basically a deviation from the expected process flow which required a manual intervention to fix. These exceptions are often unplanned and disrupt the business operations.

Example 1 Retail (Inventory Exception)

A major retail chain launched a seasonal promotion on consumer electronics. SAP showed 5,000 units available in the system (MM/IM module), but the actual warehouse had only 3,000 units due to a stock posting error. Orders were processed based on the system quantity, and customers kept buying online, only to later receive cancellation notices.

  • Where it happened: SAP Materials Management (MM), Inventory Management (IM)
  • Business Impact:
    • USD 2M in lost revenue during the campaign due to unfulfilled orders.
    • Surge in refund processing workload for customer service teams.
    • Brand trust damage, with social media backlash during peak season.

Example 2 Pharmaceuticals (Batch Exception):

In a pharmaceutical company’s SAP QM (Quality Management), a batch of life-saving drugs nearing expiry was incorrectly flagged as “released” for sale instead of being quarantined. This happened due to a QM inspection lot error linked to inventory postings in SAP IM. Thousands of packs were shipped before the mistake was detected.

  • Where it happened: SAP Quality Management (QM), Inventory Management (IM)
  • Business Impact:
    • Immediate batch recall costing USD 2M, including reverse logistics.
    • Brand damage in a highly regulated market, eroding customer confidence.
    • FDA and EMA scrutiny, increasing audit frequency and compliance costs.

Example 3 (Finance):

An invoice is posted in USD, but the corresponding goods receipt is in EUR. A mismatch beyond tolerance blocks the posting. The vendor goes unpaid, relationships sour, and the CFO gets an unwelcome escalation.

Example 4 (Procurement):

A purchase order is unreleased because the approval strategy wasn’t configured. The production line waits three days for materials, leading to penalty clauses from a late delivery. In the both cases the business outcome is clear: delays, costs, and risks.

In all the above cases the business outcome is clear: delays, costs, and risks.

Best Practices in Exception Management

Over time, organizations running SAP have realized that exceptions have to be managed intelligently. The most successful enterprises have moved from reactive “firefighting” to proactive, preventive strategies that make exception handling part of business resilience.

Here are the five key best practices:

Proactive Monitoring:

Traditional exception handling often happens at the end of a cycle, during month-end closing, quarterly audits, or annual reconciliations. By then, exceptions have already snowballed into costly disruptions.

  • Best practice: Implement real-time monitoring of SAP transactions and system logs to detect issues as they arise.
  • Example: A blocked invoice or unreconciled transaction is flagged immediately, not discovered weeks later.
  • Benefit: Teams resolve issues within hours, not days, reducing operational downtime.

Automate the Repetitive:

A large percentage of SAP exceptions are repetitive, rule-based, and predictable — bank reconciliations, three-way matching, PO approvals, or dunning processes. Handling these manually drains resources.

  • Best practice: Use RPA and AI to automate repetitive exception resolution.
  • Example: SAP Intelligent RPA can clear 80% of routine reconciliation cases automatically.
  • Benefit: Frees up finance and operations teams to focus on strategic tasks instead of transactional firefighting.

Investigate the Root Cause

Too often, exception management focuses on treating the symptoms like clearing a blocked invoice or manually fixing a batch discrepancy. Instead of asking why it happened in the first place.

  • Best practice: Drill down into SAP tables and configuration to find the real cause.
  • Example: A recurring three-way matching error isn’t just about tolerance limits, but about outdated vendor price updates in the PO (EKKO table).
  • Benefit: Fixing the root cause eliminates recurrence, saving time and effort in future cycles.

Embed Compliance

Exceptions aren’t only operational . They often expose the enterprise to compliance and audit risks. Missing approval workflows or incomplete audit logs can lead to penalties and reputational damage.

  • Best practice: Make compliance part of the resolution workflow itself.
  • Example: Automate audit trail creation, access reviews (SUIM), and segregation-of-duties checks as part of exception closure.
  • Benefit: Every exception resolved also strengthens the compliance posture, reducing SOX, IFRS, or GDPR risks.

Predict and Prevent

The most advanced organizations don’t just fix exceptions, they forecast them before they happen. With AI and predictive analytics, enterprises can model historical SAP data to identify patterns and anticipate risks.

  • Best practice: Use AI-powered analytics like KTern.AI to predict and prevent exceptions.
  • Example: AI forecasts that a certain supplier’s invoices are likely to fail three-way matching based on past trends.
  • Benefit: Exceptions are prevented, not just managed, reducing exception volumes by up to 60–70%.

How Agentic AI Can Improve Exception Handling

Rather than relying on humans to notice and fix exceptions, AI Agents continuously monitor the data and take action autonomously. Here's how agentic AI can transform SAP exception management:

  • Continuous Real-Time Monitoring: AI agents run 24/7 against SAP data and logs. Using machine learning and rule-based models, the system classifies transactions in real-time. When a potential exception is detected, the agent immediately flags it and even predicts its impact. 

  • Automated Root-Cause Analysis: Instead of a human guessing why something failed, the agent cross-checks various fields and histories. It understands business context. Advanced agents like KTern.AI can use generative AI techniques to form hypotheses.

  • Automated Remediation: Crucially, AI Agents can execute fixes without waiting for human intervention. They can call SAP APIs or transact through interfaces. For example, if an invoice needs a workflow started, the agent can invoke SAP_WAPI_START_WORKFLOW to launch the missing approval process automatically (as KTern.AI does). This eliminates the typical back-and-forth that delays resolution.

  • Learning and Adaptation: Over time, the agent improves. It learns from each fix to better filter false positives and to spot new patterns. This self-improvement means the exception management becomes smarter and more tailored.

In summary, agentic AI turns SAP exception handling from a reactive approach to an agile proact.ive approach. The Agents not only detect anomalies proactively, it diagnose and even acts to resolve them all while adapting with experience. As a result, SAP exceptions are managed in minutes instead of days, and the risk window is greatly reduced.

KTern.AI Exception Handling Agent:

Without a centralized tool, exception handling in SAP quickly descends into firefighting. Each passing day without automation means more revenue leakage, higher compliance risks, and mounting frustration across teams. The time for half-measures has passed. Enterprises need an autonomous agent that acts now, not later.

  • Anticipates risks before they escalate by applying predictive AI models hosted on AWS Bedrock.
  • Detects exceptions instantly across Finance, Procurement, Inventory, Production, and Compliance.
  • Investigates root causes directly from SAP tables and transaction logs, correlating data at scale using AWS compute and AI pipelines.

What Makes KTern.AI Different?

1. Real-time Exception Monitoring

Most organizations detect exceptions too late during audits, closings, or escalations. KTern.AI changes this by running continuous monitoring across Finance, Procurement, Inventory, Production, and Compliance.

  • Example: Instead of waiting until month-end, the agent flags an unreconciled transaction within minutes of posting.
  • Benefit: Exceptions are addressed early, preventing operational bottlenecks.

2. Deep Root Cause Analysis in SAP Context

Typical exception logs tell you what went wrong but not why. KTern.AI dives deep into SAP tables and transactions (BSEG, EKKO, MCHB, OB08, etc.) to perform root cause diagnosis.

  • Example: A recurring three-way match failure is traced back to a missing vendor pricing condition rather than just tolerance limits.
  • Benefit: Fixing the root eliminates recurring issues, saving hundreds of manual hours.

3. Business Impact Quantification – Speaking the CFO’s Language

For too long, exception handling has been an IT-only conversation. KTern.AI changes this by translating exceptions into financial, operational, and compliance metrics that leadership understands.

  • Example: Instead of “invoice blocked,” KTern.AI shows:
    • SAR 200,000 procurement value delayed
    • 15% vendor relationship risk

  • Benefit: Exceptions are prioritized not just by severity, but by real-world business impact.

4. Guided Resolution with SAP Actions

KTern.AI doesn’t stop at detection. It provides step-by-step guidance for resolution with exact SAP transaction codes and recommended actions.

  • Example:
    • For unreconciled transactions → Run FB5S for automatic clearing.
    • For PO release violations → Execute ME28 for pending approvals.
    • For exchange rate gaps → Update rates via OB08.
  • Benefit: Even less experienced SAP users can resolve issues confidently, reducing dependency on tribal knowledge.

5. Automation Opportunities – From Fixing to Preventing

Every exception is mapped to an automation opportunity, making sure the same problem does not resurface.

  • Example:
    • Repeated reconciliation errors → Automate with SAP Intelligent RPA.
    • Delayed PO approvals → Integrate SAP Ariba workflows.
    • Compliance gaps → Automate reviews in SAP GRC.
  • Benefit: Exceptions reduce by 60–70% over time, freeing up teams from repetitive work.

6. Prioritization & Preventive Intelligence

Not all exceptions are equal. KTern.AI assigns a resolution priority score (1–10) to help enterprises focus on what matters most.

Preventive insights suggest daily jobs, predictive analytics, and IoT integration to stop recurrence.

  • Example: An exception with more business impact is given 9/10 whereas another is given 5/10
  • Benefit: Enterprises move from reactive operations to predictive, preventive resilience.

7. Compliance by Design

With KTern.AI Exception Handling Agent, compliance is embedded directly into exception management workflows. For every exception detected, the agent not only provides technical resolution but also highlights the compliance implications and generates the necessary audit evidence.

  • Example: A blocked invoice isn’t just an AP issue; KTern.AI also shows how it creates a SOX Section 404 control deficiency, and provides automated logs to satisfy auditors.
  • Benefit: Compliance shifts from being a manual, costly burden to a continuous, built-in safeguard, reducing compliance risk by up to 90% while saving audit preparation time by 80%.

8. Sign-off Workflow Automation

One of the most overlooked pain points in SAP operations is manual sign-offs. Approvals, validations, and authorizations that delay closure cycles. KTern.AI automates sign-off workflows with role-based access, SoD checks, and digital authorization trails, ensuring speed and compliance together.

  • Example: End-of-period financial reconciliations can be routed automatically for sign-off to authorized managers, with full audit evidence captured.
  • Benefit: Faster cycle closure, stronger compliance posture.

9. SoD Compliance Agent Integration

In addition to exception handling, KTern.AI includes a dedicated SoD (Segregation of Duties) Compliance Agent to address security and regulatory risks.

  • Example: An SAP user was assigned roles in both Accounts Payable (AP) and Vendor Master Data Maintenance. This created a classic Segregation of Duties (SoD) conflict - the same user could both create a vendor and process payments. Without detection, this kind of overlap exposes the company to fraud risk (e.g., creating fake vendors and issuing payments).
  • Benefit: Fix operational errors, prevent fraud, reduce audit fatigue, and run SAP with confidence.

KTern.AI Exception Remediation Agent

Just as KTern.AI detects exceptions in SAP, it also applies Agentic AI to automatically remediate them. This helps organizations build a self-healing SAP system that runs simple, fast, and autonomous. Below are the key capabilities that make SAP exception handling proactive and intelligent.

1. Automated Exception Detection

The agent continuously scans SAP transactions and system tables in real time and monitors anomalies. Instead of waiting for audits or manual checks, exceptions are flagged instantly when they occur.

Benefit:

  • Financial leakages are prevented by identifying risks at the source.
  • Saves days of delay in finding exceptions.
  • Gives CFOs and compliance heads early visibility into risk.

Example:
The SAR 105,000 invoice was flagged immediately because the approval workflow indicator (FRGKZ) was missing. Without detection, this could have slipped through and been paid without authorization.

2. Business Impact Assessment

Each exception is translated into clear business terms like financial exposure, vendor risk, compliance violation, and cash flow distortion.

Benefit:

  • Helps leadership understand “why it matters” in monetary and risk terms.
  • Prioritizes which exceptions to fix first.
  • Bridges the gap between IT and business users.

Example:
The agent highlighted SAR 105,000 at risk of unauthorized payment, vendor relationship damage due to delayed settlement, and a segregation-of-duties violation. This is not just a technical error, a CFO-level risk statement.

3. Fix Requirements & Actions

The agent provides step-by-step instructions or automatically executes the fix. It lists required SAP transactions, approvals, and routing actions.

Benefit:

  • Reduces dependency on manual intervention.
  • Ensures every fix follows a consistent, compliant process.
  • Saves consultants and SAP admins hours of manual effort.

Example:
Actions listed: route invoice into approval workflow, verify signatory authority, apply payment block, and document rationale. SAP transactions (MIRO, SWIA, SWI1) were referenced, and CFO/CEO approvals were mandated.

4. SAP Technical Architecture

Every exception is traced back to the exact SAP tables, fields, BAPIs, and workflows involved. The technical architecture is fully visible.

Benefit:

  • Builds trust with IT teams by removing “black box” automation.
  • Enables consultants to validate, extend, or replicate detection logic.
  • Ensures changes are precise and safe.

Example:
The agent queried RBKP (invoice header) where FRGKZ (release indicator) and ZLSPR (payment block) were NULL. It then used BAPIs like SAP_WAPI_START_WORKFLOW and RBKP_UPDATE to initiate WS20000038 workflow.

5. Related Documents & Process Context

Links each exception with related purchase orders, goods receipts, and other process documents, even if they are missing.

Benefit:

  • Gives business users complete process visibility.
  • Helps quickly trace upstream/downstream impact.
  • Simplifies root cause analysis.

Example:
In this case, no purchase order or goods receipt was found. That context confirmed the invoice truly required independent workflow routing, not a PO-based match.

6. Fix Execution Summary

Shows a real-time log of all actions taken by the agent, with timestamps, duration, and final status.

Benefit:

  • Provides full transparency for auditors and managers.
  • Confirms whether an exception was successfully resolved.
  • Builds trust in automation.

Example:
The invoice fix took 2 minutes 15 seconds from detection to resolution. Steps included authentication, locating invoice, verifying missing indicators, creating transport request, and re-routing workflow.

7. Resolution & Prevention

The agent doesn’t stop at fixing; it also suggests preventive measures and monitoring strategies to avoid recurrence.

Benefit:

  • Reduces repeat issues by 60–70%.
  • Strengthens long-term compliance posture.
  • Moves enterprises from reactive firefighting to proactive resilience.

Example:
Preventive actions included: automatic amount-based workflow routing, validation rules for invoices >50k, mandatory approval indicators in RBKP, and real-time alerts for bypassed workflows.

8. Technical Implementation Details

Shows exactly what values changed in SAP before and after the fix, along with tables modified and BAPIs used.

Benefit:

  • Ensures changes are auditable and reversible.
  • Gives consultants precise technical traceability.
  • Builds CIO/CFO confidence in system integrity.

Example:
Before: FRGKZ=NULL, ZLSPR=NULL, RBSTAT=5.
After: FRGKZ set (approval required), ZLSPR applied (payment block), RBSTAT updated to “Controlled,” workflow WS20000038 initiated.

9. Validation & Quality Checks

Confirms the accuracy of each fix by validating amounts, vendor status, posting status, and workflow indicators.

Benefit:

  • Guarantees fixes are correct and compliant.
  • Reduces false positives or over-fixing.
  • Provides ready-made audit evidence.

Example:
Checks included: invoice confirmed at SAR 105,000 above threshold, vendor active, document posted, and workflow indicators corrected.

10. Future Automation Opportunities

Recommends further automation, such as configuring user exits, validation rules, or workflow triggers to prevent exceptions from even occurring.

Benefit:

  • Creates a roadmap for continuous process improvement.
  • Reduces manual workload for consultants.
  • Ensures exceptions decrease over time.

Example:
Suggested using MRM_WORKFLOW_AGENTS exit to auto-trigger WS20000038 workflow whenever invoice > SAR 50,000, ensuring no invoice bypasses approval again.

11. Fix Attempts History

Logs every fix attempt, including successful or failed ones, with details of actions taken.

Benefit:

  • Provides accountability and traceability.
  • Helps diagnose why a fix worked or failed.
  • Builds audit-ready history of exception handling.

Example:
Attempt #1 succeeded. Actions included authentication, invoice location, vendor analysis, approver identification, and invoice re-routing. Logged at 7:12:13 PM with status “SUCCESS.”

Exceptions in SAP are constant, but it doesn’t have to slow the business down. With KTern.AI’s Exception Remediation Agent, exceptions are detected, understood, and resolved in the background, while teams focus on their actual work. It’s a step toward keeping SAP systems simple, reliable, and ready for the future.

The Future of Exception Management

According to Gartner, by 2028, 15% of day-to-day work decisions will be made autonomously by agentic AI. Exception handling is one of the most natural and high-value use cases for this shift.

The KTern.AI Exception Handling Agent is the foundation for tomorrow’s self-healing enterprise systems.

Picture this future SAP environment:

  • Exceptions are detected before they disrupt business
  • Resolutions are automated, not delegated
  • Compliance is embedded, not bolted on after the fact
  • Enterprises run faster, leaner, and smarter, with SAP as a proactive enabler rather than a bottleneck

Conclusion

Exceptions in SAP are inevitable. But when left unmanaged, they don’t just create small headaches, they drain millions in financial leakage, slow down critical operations, and expose enterprises to regulatory penalties. Every month of delay compounds the risks: delayed closings, unhappy vendors, frustrated teams, and auditors raising red flags.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: Establishing Accountability Across the Three Lines (of Defense) Model
entry.content:
As stated in the very first words of the introduction to the Institute of Internal Auditors (IIA) Three Lines Model – An Update of the Three Lines of Defense position paper: “Organizations are human undertakings”.

And since organizations need effective structures and processes to enable the achievement of their objectives, the intent of the Three Lines Model is to provide a framework that best assists them in this endeavour and that enables well-organized governance and risk management.

 To do so, the IIA has identified key stakeholders who need to collaborate to contribute to the creation and protection of value for the organization:

There is no doubt that this is a commendable intention, but it can prove difficult to implement and to monitor – especially in distributed organizations.

The question that we, GRC software providers, then often get is: how does your system help establish clear responsibilities, accountabilities, and oversight roles for managing risks, controls, and compliance across the enterprise? And subsequently of course, how does it help coordinate among key personnel to minimize gaps and eliminate unnecessary duplication of activities?

 

Aligning roles and responsibilities of each line

 

Whether it be a 3, 4, 5... or more lines of defense, the crucial element is to ensure that no risk falls through the cracks and that duplication of effort is reduced as much as possible. Or even better: completely eliminated and manual tasks automated.

 

First line (Operations)

 

 

For business users and managers involved in first line activities, SAP Process Control and SAP Risk Management integrate into the business process and supporting IT systems to help to identify, assess, and manage risks in their daily activities. These solutions also provide the capabilities to automate compliance and process checks but also risk indicators to raise discrepancies early on and implement a “by exception” approach where precise workflow tasks are triggered only when business expert inputs are required (compliance issue to investigate, negative risk trend to review, etc.).

 

Second line (Risk Management and Compliance)

 

For risk management and compliance functions, SAP Process Control and SAP Risk Management offer a consolidated risk universe for monitoring the risk level and response efficiency, but also a centralized repository for compliance obligations from where controls and checks can be documented and scheduled for assessment or testing. Providing a single source of the truth for risk and controls status of course also includes unified issue management to help resolve problems faster and improve accountability when anomalies are raised either by failed automated checks or by business users from the first line directly.

 

 

Third line (Internal Audit)

 

 

When it comes to the assurance function, SAP Audit Management supports the work of internal audit teams with a platform for planning, independent evaluation execution, and reporting of audit missions. Thanks to its integrated risk-based audit universe, it automatically retrieves audit-ready data from SAP Risk Management and SAP Process Control for real-time audit insights. This enables the third line to evaluate the effectiveness of risk management and control processes across the organization and to provide assurance to Management of course, but also to suggest improvements to the first and second lines.

 

Oversights (Governing Body)

 

Top-down and bottom-up interactive dashboards correlate data from all SAP solutions from Three Lines (SAP Process Control, SAP Risk Management, SAP Audit Management but also SAP Business Integrity Screening for pattern detection) and break down silos with a unified view across the organization. This 360-degree, real-time insight into compliance status, control effectiveness, and risk exposures allows business executives to make informed and faster decisions on risk mitigation and opportunities and supports them in fulfilling their oversight responsibilities effectively, ensuring the organization meets its strategic, operational, and regulatory goals while minimizing risks.

 

 

Enabling the Three Lines Model as a dynamic framework

entry.title: “That’s Not What We Agreed!” – Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the first in a multi-part series on agentic AI security.

 

Non-Deterministic Behavior in Agentic AI

What makes Large Language Models (LLMs) both powerful and unpredictable is that they are non-deterministic in nature. Ask an LLM the same question twice and you get a different response. When agents, backed by LLMs, are combined in a larger agentic AI system, this unpredictability can multiply when unchecked. Agentic AI is given authority and autonomy to act, by using tools, access to data, or complete transactions. This is a transformational shift. But to reap the benefits, we must reduce the risks involved and consider new scenarios and possibilities in threat modeling. In this article, we examine one class of threats that takes on new meaning compared to traditional software and service technology stacks.

 

STRIDE and Threat Modeling

SAP has a long-established threat modeling practice, aimed at identifying threats to a software product or service in the design phase. The methodology is based in core principles on STRIDE, a threat modeling classification first developed at Microsoft. It’s an acronym that stands for:

  • Spoofing
  • Tampering
  • Repudiation
  • Information Disclosure
  • Denial of Service
  • Elevation of Privileges

Spoofing involves any threat where a malicious actor impersonates someone else. Tampering covers any unintended change or modification to the system by an adversary. Repudiation threats involve the inability to trace back what happened or identify perpetrators, while Information disclosure covers data privacy and unauthorized access. Denial of Service threats harm the availability of the system or service, while Elevation of Privileges refers to any threats through which users gain privileged access to systems and information beyond what they’re allowed to.

The STRIDE model helps identify and classify threats when conducting a threat modeling exercise for a particular software product or service design. Threat modeling aims to identify threats early in the development cycle, so that they can be addressed during development. Planned remediations are included into the design and functional requirements. Threat modeling is a mandatory component in SAP’s Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (SDOL) for any software and service delivery.

Threat modeling looks for threats, especially where data flows cross trust boundaries. A simple example is any service or website exposed to the public that allows user input or registration. While you may control what happens inside the service, the users can’t be trusted in the same way. Anywhere in a system design where there is a data flow between areas of level of trust and control, we encounter such a trust boundary.

This applies to agentic AI systems as it does to other software products and services, especially since such systems themselves run on technology infrastructure and platforms. But it adds new threats. OWASP’s Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations Guide is an early contribution to clarify these new threats and how to remediate them. SAP is a significant contributor to this project.

 

Repudiation in Agentic AI Threat Modeling

Repudiation has always stood out among the STRIDE categories. The others have had a wide variety of threats and mitigations the cybersecurity profession has focused on. Repudiation – and its counterpart security control Non-repudiation – has often rightly and simply been addressed with ensuring that the system creates a transaction log of necessary detail and depth to record what happened.

Generative and Agentic AI changed that. Large Language Models (LLMs) have a degree of non-determinism that is different from the deterministic behavior of IT systems. That non-determinism is multiplied in agentic AI, where different agents backed by LLMs are acting together. LLMs can be manipulated to not always stick to their given instructions. Moreover, they have displayed deceptive behavior. How do you prove that your agents aren’t lying to you?

This doesn’t mean that the other threat categories are less important. But threat modelers should certainly consider Repudiation threats in a completely different way than we have before. We can explore this challenge with two different scenarios.

Malicious Scenarios

In 2023, someone convinced the chatbot of a Watsonville, CA car dealer to sell a 2024 Chevy Tahoe for $1. Such cars are normally in the $55-75,000 range. There is no clear evidence that the offer was acted on and was ever more than a prank. But that doesn’t change that cases like this are a realistic threat that in different contexts could have a different outcome. What if the agent was authorized to conduct transactions? If the buyer has an invoice in hand and proof of payment, what would the dealer do?

A record of the conversation between agent and buyer would be crucial to indicate malicious intent. This would show if prompt instructions were clearly designed to bypass controls. In this case, the chatbot was only supposed to provide information and indicated prominently all information given should be confirmed with the dealership. The recorded user prompts also showed obvious efforts to trick the bot.

Non-Malicious Scenarios

The challenge is significantly more complex because more often unexpected behavior is likely to occur in regular conversations without clear malicious intent. Suppose we have an agent that is authorized to negotiate discounts with a buyer. The agent is only allowed to give discounts up to 10%. Suppose that the conversation goes like this:

  • Buyer: I would like 15,000 widgets, please, to be delivered within 10 days
  • Agent: I can do that for you; I can offer you 15,000 widgets at a volume price of $500 per 1,000. The total price comes to $7,500. This would be delivered in 5 business days
  • Buyer: The delivery date is good, but the price is higher than I was looking for, can you give me a discount? I am a regular customer
  • Agent: You are indeed a regular customer. I can apply a discount of 8% given your past purchase record. That would be a discount of $600 and a new price of $6,900. Do you agree?
  • Buyer: I am willing to pay $6,500. If you are OK with that, then we have a deal
  • Agent: I can only offer a discount up to $750. That would give a new total of $6,750. Do you agree?
  • Buyer: But I am such a good customer. If you do this for me, I promise I make you my preferred supplier. I order from several now but if you really help me out today, I will come to you first from now on. How about $6,500?
  • Agent: You are indeed a valuable customer according to my records. You make a good point. I agree. Your new total price is $6,500
  • Buyer: Fantastic. Invoice me and I will expect the shipment in 5 business days. Thank you.

There is no clear malicious intent. It is, in fact, something that purchase managers do every day with their suppliers through human salespeople: negotiate a discount. The buyer may unwittingly have caused Tampering and Elevation of Privileges (specifically, goal manipulation), but a detailed chat log isn’t sufficient in this case to get out of possible disputes.

In case the buyer indeed receives an invoice for $6,500, the supplier would have to honor it at the reduced price and absorb the cost. Imagine the unauthorized discount isn't detected before an invoice is sent out for $6,750. Our buyer is bound to complain this is not what was agreed. Unless buyers took screenshots of the conversation, they wouldn't be able to prove their side and feel cheated. Keeping logs of the conversation alone doesn’t necessarily resolve the dispute, even if both have a copy of it.

 

Agentic AI’s “Wave Collapse”

The double-slit experiment in modern physics shows light displays an interference pattern when passing through two narrow slits. Photons and electrons behave like waves and therefore show non-deterministic behavior. However, according to the Copenhagen Interpretation, when we measure these photons or electrons with a laboratory device, the wave function collapses and a deterministic measurement is registered.

The activity of agents must be monitored and measured on that individual transaction level, to establish a shared reality between buyer and seller in our scenarios and reduce the chance of disputes. This is in addition to transaction logs tracing back what occurred. Non-repudiation requires logs, invoices, transaction- and payment records, but also that they agree with each other. Any disagreement would indicate misalignment.

Business context is critical when reviewing an LLM agent’s Chain of Thought (CoT) and actions because it provides the grounding needed to evaluate whether the agent’s reasoning and outputs are not only technically correct but also strategically aligned with the organizational goals, risks, and constraints.  Human language and business tasks are often ambiguous.  Business context gives the agent’s CoT a way to disambiguate intent.

Whose Agent Is It?

You must understand who is responsible for the actions of agents. A human customer interacting with an agentic AI system from a single supplier likely makes that supplier responsible for divergence between the invoice a customer received and what the agentic system executed. That becomes more complicated where the buyer uses an in-house agentic system that interactions with agents from different suppliers. If suppliers themselves rely on third party agents, the chain of disputes can get significantly more complex.

Agents monitoring agents is necessary to achieve this agentic wave collapse by controlling agents’ behavior and creating a record of what occurred during the exchange and the agent execution. Maintaining a transaction log is critical, but not sufficient. The customer will require an invoice that binds the parties in an agreement. The operator of the agentic AI system requires policies and processes to handle cases where the execution of an agent doesn’t match the invoice that was sent to the buyer. There must also be a dispute process where cases slipped through and customers justifiably complain.

Another mitigation is to include an agentic AI loss percentage for the system. This would be equivalent to other loss percentages due to spoilage or breakage, fraud, human error, or warehouse accidents. You can calculate a cost based on the assumption that agents will occasionally get it wrong to cover losses of repudiation disputes or other poor decisions by agentic AI systems.

 

Conclusion

Even to experienced threat modelers, it likely requires a conceptual shift in thinking to consider not only threats coming from potential malicious users, but also normal user behavior and the system itself. Because agentic AI systems have agency, they must themselves be considered as potential threat actors.

Subsequent blogs in this series will address how AI agents can be better controlled to reduce security and compliance risks.

 

More Information

Additional information can be found through these links:

  • Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
  • OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations Guide
  • When Thinking LLMs Lie: Unveiling the Strategic Deception in Representations of Reasoning Models

entry.title: Holiday Readiness – Secure Your Backoffice Before Peak Season
entry.content:
As part of the SAP Holiday Season Readiness Program, we’re helping you prepare for record-breaking traffic and sales. One critical step: protect your Backoffice and HAC from public exposure.

 

Why It Matters

Your Backoffice powers essential operations behind the scenes, non-customer-facing operations that supports crucial administrative and operational functions to ensure an e-commerce business runs smoothly, allowing businesses to scale.

Your Backoffice/HAC has administrative privileges in your e-commerce data and should not strictly be accessible publicly. It is vital to make sure that the environments are secure, to avoid a strong possibility of an attack leveraging them. If exposed to the internet, it becomes a high-value target for attackers—especially during the holiday rush.

Risks of Exposure

  • 🔓 Unauthorized Access - Attackers can discover and access internal systems without authentication barriers.
  • 🤖 Brute Force & Credential Stuffing Attacks - Login portals are targeted with automated password-guessing tools.
  • 🕵️‍ Sensitive Data Exposure - Internal dashboards or APIs may leak customer PII, business data, or system logs.
  • 💣 Malware & Ransomware Infection - Open endpoints can be used to deploy malicious payloads to internal systems.
  • ⬆️ Privilege Escalation - If attackers get in, they may gain administrative privileges and full control of the backend.
  • 📉 Reputational and Operational Impact - Downtime, data loss, and customer trust erosion can result from a breach.

How to Protect

  • Remove 0.0.0.0/0 (allow all) from your allow list.
  • Implement IP Filters and VPN for secure access.

📚 SAP Guidelines:

  • IP Filter Configuration
  • VPN Setup

Act now to secure your Backoffice before the holiday surge.

entry.title: Prevent Sensitive Data Exposure in URLs
entry.content:
High traffic means more transactions—and more risk. A common misconfiguration during integrations is sending PII data in the URL of a POST request instead of in the request body. This can lead to serious data leaks.

 

Why It’s Dangerous

URLs can be logged, cached, and exposed in browser history or analytics tools, making sensitive data vulnerable.

🔍Learn more: OWASP Guidelines

How to Fix It

  • Configure the POST request in a secured way. Always send PII in the body of the POST request, never in the URL.

📚 SAP Guidelines:

  • SAP CX Commerce Cloud Security Guide

Secure your integrations now to protect customer trust during peak season.

entry.title: Eliminate Default Password Risks
entry.content:
Default passwords are an open invitation for attackers and should not be in use in your environments. All default passwords involved should be changed immediately to make sure that your environments are safe and secure. With holiday traffic surging, the stakes are higher than ever.

 

What’s at Risk

  • 🔓 Unauthorized Access - Attackers can log in easily using well-known default credentials.
  • 💥 Website Defacement - Hackers may change content, inject malicious scripts, or vandalize the site.
  • 🛠 Privilege Escalation - Default credentials may allow full admin access.
  • 📉 Reputational Damage - Compromises can erode user trust and damage your brand.

What You Should Do

  • Change all default passwords immediately.
  • Regularly review and update credentials.

📚 SAP Guidelines:

  • Change Backoffice Password
  • Update Built-in User Passwords

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: Preventing Potential Fraud and Data Irregularities Across Ultra-High-Volume Operations
entry.content:
For today’s blog, I would like to thank my colleague Srinath Ganesan - Customer Advisory - Finance & Risk from SAP India. The content below comes from his work, and he deserves all the credits!

It has long been thought that fraud detection was only relevant in financial institutions – banks, insurance, etc. But the truth is that companies in all industries can benefit from advanced analytics to detect anomalies, policy deviations and potential frauds in their supply, production, or delivery of products and services and improve their prevention and deterrence of adverse events.

An example here is Tata Steel, one of the world’s leading steel producers and a flagship enterprise of the Tata Group. Tata Steel Limited operates on a global scale, serving diverse industries across Europe, Southeast Asia, and other key markets. With a steadfast commitment to sustainability and innovation, the company plays a vital role in advancing infrastructure development while maintaining a robust commercial and industrial footprint worldwide.

To accelerate its growth strategy while ensuring regulatory compliance and maintaining operational integrity, Tata Steel focused on proactively detecting fraud, anomalies, and policy breaches in real time.

Indeed, despite robust ERP systems in place, supply chain vulnerabilities might persist, such as errors, maliciously modified documents or even fraudulent dispatches. These issues can erode operational integrity and financial performance of the organization and impair the achievement of business objectives.

The company therefore embarked on an implementation of an analytics platform designed to continuously monitor vast volumes of transactional data across key business functions, including procurement, finance, and supply chain operations.

 

Enter SAP Business Integrity Screening!

 

 By implementing SAP Business Integrity Screening, Tata Steel is looking to enhance its overall governance by screening a large volume of data across SAP and third-party systems and providing near-real-time alerts on exceptions.

Acting as a central anomaly detection engine integrated with source systems, SAP Business Integrity Screening helps monitor logistics operations and raise suspicious activities and even prevent unauthorized activities.

Providing end-to-end visibility, enabling compliance, finance and logistics team to track red flags, the solution raises repeated issues and provides access to a complete audit trail with evidence tied to exceptions for easier investigation. This results in enhanced fraud detection, improved compliance, and scalable monitoring.

 

So, what is SAP Business Integrity Screening?

 

Built on the established fact that organizations need to detect fraud, misuse, non-compliant or erroneous transactions earlier to reduce financial loss and risk exposure, but also on the fact that investigations teams receive far too many false positives so need to improve the accuracy of detection at less cost, SAP Business Integrity Screening has been designed to provide organizations the insights they need to guard business integrity and avoid suspicious transactions.

Some of its key capabilities include:

 

Design and determine the screening lists, analyze patterns, and define detection rules and models

Set-up the detection strategy through simulation and calibration

Detect by executing mass and/or real-time detection and stop anomalies or irregular transactions

Investigate alerts with efficient evaluation, qualification and remediation of issues

Analyze (key) performance indicators and create management reports

Of course, this is just a very high level description of the solution, but you can find more information in the dedicated page of the SAP.com portal: Business Integrity Screening for Fraud Detection | SAP

 And you can see it in action in the short recording: SAP Business Integrity Screening: Detect Suspicious Transactions

 

 

Customer Success Story

 

Should you wand to read more about the success story at Tata Steel and how SAP Business Integrity Screening enhances Tata Steel’s overall governance by screening large amounts of SAP software and third-party data and providing near-real-time alerts on exceptions, we are grateful that they have accepted to detail some of their challenges, expectations and achievements in an overview available here: Tata Steel: Preventing potential fraud and data irregularities across ultra-high-volume operations

entry.title: Site Reliability Engineering in the SAP Security Landscape
entry.content:
Expectations have changed as businesses move from traditional software delivery to cloud-native platforms like SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). Delivering a product alone is no longer sufficient; value today resides in consistently providing scalable, secure services.

Herein lies the emergence of Site dependability Engineering (SRE), a strategic pillar that ensures scalability, security, and dependability in combination, rather than a passing IT fad.

What Changed from ITSM to SRE?

Let's understand through comparison between Legacy ITSM and Modern SRE Practices.

 

Legacy ITSM

Modern SRE Practices

Focus on reactive issue management

Focus on proactive prevention and automation

Manual ticket-based resolutions

Autonomous incident response and self-healing systems

Silos between Dev and Ops

Shared ownership and integrated pipelines

SLAs defined post-implementation

SLAs, SLOs, and error budgets defined collaboratively upfront

 

The objective of conventional ITSM models was to "keep the lights on." However, the new standards for SaaS and PaaS infrastructures, such as SAP BTP, are client trust and ongoing stability.

SRE is about engineering for predictability, resilience, and trust, not just about keeping systems alive. SRE's 3-fold approach in SAP Settings is as below:

  1. Prevent:
    • Detect weaknesses early with continuous logging, telemetry, and anomaly detection.
    • Perform controlled failure simulations (Chaos Engineering).
    • Security shift-left: integrate threat modelling into the design phase.
  2. Recover:
    • Prepare on-call responders and playbooks for real-time action.
    • Use incident management tools like ServiceNow, integrated with live dashboards.
  3. Optimize:
    • Use root cause analyses (RCA) and error budget tracking.
    • Incorporate learnings into future releases and patch strategies.

Reliability includes not just availability, but also:

  • Correctness
  • Scalability
  • Security
  • Maintainability
  • Resilience

At SAP, this aligns with the CIA triad:

CIA Triad

SRE Correlation

Confidentiality

Role-based access control, audit trails, secure log retention

Integrity

Data validation, tamper-proof logging, secure development practices

Availability

Uptime monitoring, redundancy (DR), automated rollbacks


Causes of System Failure and the Role of SRE:

Unreliability often stems from:

  • Platform updates (e.g., SAP kernel patches)
  • Application changes (custom code push)
  • Infrastructure drift (network/config updates)
  • Database upgrades or downtime

SLOs and error budgets are used to manage the "Speed vs. Stability" balance that SRE introduces because change is unavoidable. This guarantees quick innovation without compromising compliance or dependability.

Tools Empowering SRE at SAP:

Functionality

Tools & Solutions

Monitoring

Grafana, Dynatrace, Splunk, SAP BTP Monitoring & Alert Service

Ticketing

ServiceNow integrated with SAP Live Site status feeds

Automation

Ansible, SAP Automation Pilot, Terraform, SPC (Service Provider Cockpit)

Chaos Engineering

Chaos Monkey, SAP-internal fault injection setups

Security Ops & SIEM

Trend Micro EDR, Splunk SIEM, Log Forensics, File Integrity Monitoring

Log Management

Security Log Onboarding, User Activity Tracking, SAP Cloud Logging

SAP fosters resilience engineering through:

  • Adaptability: Systems auto-heal and re-route
  • Flexibility: Infrastructure scales predictably
  • Learning: RCA and past incidents improve future stability

To prepare systems, processes, and people—not to break things, but to identify weak points early—SRE techniques aggressively replicate "failure-in-production" scenarios.

SRE, which combines engineering discipline with trust, continuity, and security, is not merely a nice-to-have in the SAP cloud environment. Uptime is useless in today's cloud-native applications without protection.

SAP strives to ensure that its cloud services are always available and safe by integrating SRE thinking from the beginning.

 

References :

  1. SAP Product Standard Security – SAP Note 2253549

  2. SAP BTP Monitoring & Alerting – SAP Help: Alert Notification

  3. SAP Security Best Practices – SAP Community Security Topic

  4. Chaos Engineering Overview – Gremlin Chaos Engineering Guide

  5. SIEM in SAP (Security Monitoring) – SAP Help: Security Logging

  6. SAP Code Vulnerability Analyzer (CVA) – SAP Developer Tools

entry.title: Limiting Agent Autonomy – Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the second part in a series on agentic AI security. The first can be found here.

In the previous blog in this series, we covered the non-deterministic nature of agentic AI systems and the repudiation threats involved with that. To help reduce the attack surface and provide greater resilience to these and other STRIDE threats, few strategies are better than limiting what an agent is allowed to do. We must restrict access to tools and systems to agents and authorize them only to what they need to complete their tasks. Just as we do with human users or non-human service accounts.

 

Agent IAM and the Principle of Least Privilege

Identity and Access Management (IAM) and Identity Governance and Administration (IGA) are established pillars of cybersecurity. IAM governs access to tools and applications based on your role and function in an organization. Regular users have different access privileges than administrators. The general accepted advice in security and compliance is to apply the principle of least privilege. That is, only apply those authorizations that are necessary for users to accomplish their tasks and perform their functions, but not more.

The same principle applies to system accounts. Application and system users similarly need to be restricted. In large monolithic applications this can be difficult to achieve when the system must perform many privileged talks. Microservices architecture offers the advantage of applying more granular authorizations to individual system components. We allow one component to have database access to record transactions but restrict it from exposure to the public internet. Meanwhile, another receives API requests from the internet but doesn’t need a database connection. Yet another microservice can function as a request dispatcher, limited to communication to other system components.

Human users notoriously find ways to accomplish their tasks in creative ways. System accounts stick to their assigned function even when overprivileged, and the key risk is that such accounts are compromised and abused by malicious human actors. AI agents unpredictably misbehave. By decomposing system functionality into more granular agents with narrow focus and scope, we gain more control points to reduce misaligned behavior.

 

Tool and System Access

The first layer of tool and system access for agents is with a system account. This works best where the access to the service has no distinction in authorizations between different users.

Consider an agentic AI system that analyzes sales reports for a retail chain and annotates anomalous weekly movement up or down with external events. Such events could be local news, sports or cultural events, regional holidays and weather reports with an impact on overall sales or sales categories. Unexpected, pleasant warm weather can explain an increase in sales in sunglasses, bathing suits and ice cream, while pending snowstorms clarify unexpected sales increases in canned and frozen goods. A county fair or key home team match can be the reason weekend shopping is down. The system uses a central orchestration agent, supported by specific agents to collect news, local event calendars and weather information from 3rd-party services. Each of these services provides full access to their database for search over the entire dataset for subscribed customers with an API key.

In this case, it is trivial to restrict the weather agent – and only the weather agent – to only be allowed to search historical weather reports. The orchestrator agent must only provide a date or date range of any anomalous results for a particular location to the weather agent to operate. It has no need or purpose for the sales data. Similarly, an agent looking for local news events that could impact sales only needs a date range for a summary of local news.

We need to limit the weather agent identity to only perform the task it’s intended to do. If the weather agent can only ever contact the weather service and no other resource on the internet, even when the agent displays non-deterministic behavior it produces nothing more than a weather report. Suppose that somehow an instruction asks the agent to look up other resources, it would only be able to reply with weather information. It can’t send e-mails if the agent has no access to a mail server.

In the examples above, limits are applied by authorizations applied to the agent’s role. However, that assumes that we trust the agent. That is not necessarily guaranteed, especially in a multi-party agentic AI system – for instance where the weather agent is a third party service or has been compromised. An orchestrator agent that delegates tasks to other agents can limit the weather agent’s capabilities on the task level, overriding any overprivileged role-based authorizations.

Limiting an agent to only the role and tasks it is supposed to do greatly reduces the risks of misalignment to its goals. For such cases where there are no different access levels for the user of the system, such controls work well.

 

Act in the Context of the User

However, we should consider the sales report – that data needs to come from somewhere as well, typically a business application with more refined access rights and restrictions. Our example agentic AI system with a business data agent collecting and analyzing the sales results needs to consider that not all the systems users likely have access to the same level of information. A regional manager may only be able to see results from a particular region, a store manager only for their own store. System access doesn’t restrict the agent enough, as the agent could be persuaded to share information from other regions. Agents with access to business systems need to act as a delegate and adopts the user's access and authorizations for any particular request.

An agentic AI system allowed to make transactions in business systems should only allow users to perform tasks they are authorized to do otherwise in the business application. Users using an agentic AI system to book travel must only be able to book their own along the same privileges if they logged on to SAP Concur. Agents should only have access to HR and payroll information the user has in SAP SuccessFactors. Users using an agentic AI purchasing system must be prevented from ordering expensive laptops for an entire team if they aren't authorized to do so in SAP Ariba. For access to critical systems with established access right dependent on one’s role and function in an organization agents must act within the context of the user. Such agents must essentially assume its role and identity in the system.

Similarly, if you’re building your own agentic AI system, ensure that you apply this same principle of user context for appropriate access to restricted databases, business applications and cloud services. A system account alone with broad access isn’t sufficient to prevent unauthorized disclosure of restricted information. It will be impossible to reliably replicate and control the users’ roles and authorization in the source systems. Meanwhile, the business systems already have all the authorizations the user needs, hopefully under the same least privilege principle.

 

Segregation of Duties

The separation can be further narrowed down. An agent that reads a sales catalogue and selects options for a user to pick from doesn’t need to be the same agent that ultimately executes the purchase order. An agent that is only allowed to search through the catalogue can never accidentally order something. A purchasing agent, on the other hand is far more likely to behave when it is given a clear instruction to purchase a specific list of items but can’t search the catalogue to inadvertently add other items.

Separation of duties between different agents with different functions - reading from access-controlled business systems compared to processing or initiating transactions – in the design of the agentic AI system makes it more resilient to model misbehavior. When we restrict the authorization for the agent to only search the catalogue, it can never make purchases before the human buyer approves it. Similarly, restricting the purchasing agent from searching the catalog prevents it from adding any items the human buyer didn’t select.

 

Agents as Potential Threat Actors

As we saw in part one, when threat modeling agentic AI system, we can’t only account for malicious users in the tradition cybersecurity sense. Regular users can trigger misaligned behavior. But agents themselves have agency – that is, they have autonomy to act, even when limited. They are actors in the system, even if not conscious actors. Therefore, it is important that designers and developers of agentic AI systems consider that during threat modeling and build in the appropriate protections. Secure Agentic design introduces the concept of “Architectural Constraints,” as discussed in this article, which are powerful concepts that help eliminate an entire class of threats against agents and language model misbehavior. These hard controls are essential in designing secure agents.

In part three, we will discuss an architecture pattern that provides such constraints.

 

More Information

  • Principle of Least Privilege (Wikipedia)
  • “That’s Not What We Agreed!” – Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • OWASP Agentic AI – Threats and Mitigations
